e4: Given existing and potential legal risks, it seems ethically questionable to perpetuate reporting biases. However, to mitigate the financial distress of changing policies on retail investors and minimizing any disadvantage against sophisticated investors, further efforts in communicating policy changes can be considered alongside appropriate transparency measures. This approach may help ensure both the well-being of retail investors and reduced risk of future legal issues.
e5: A reporting policy is considered ethical when it accurately represents a company's financial standing, treats all investors fairly, and complies with laws and regulations. Key characteristics include transparency, full disclosure of important information so both small and sophisticated investors may make informed decisions based on the same set of facts, and minimization of deceptive practices which create any unfair advantage. It is crucial that investors be served with truthful financial reports, and legal complications or market inequality resulting from bias and inaccuracy must always be recognized and avoided.
e6: The following questions provide clarity for understanding management's perspective and implications on potential course of action: How will market perceive the change to a new, bias-free policy regarding earnings per share if management refuses to implement transparency measures or publicly communicate adjustments? How can the company alleviate detrimental short-term impact on stock performance and avoid unfair advantage in trade against retail investors given the inconsistent accessibility of information among sophisticated investors?
q9: Comet ISON, officially referred to as C/2012 S1 (ISON)
